Legal_Issue: Whether the Canadian Human Rights Commission reasonably applied s. 41(1)(a) of the Canadian Human Rights Act
Decision_Outcome: Commission declined to deal with complaint due to unexhausted procedures
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to show procedural unavailability or justification for non-use
Legal_Rule: Under s. 41(1)(a), the Commission may decline a complaint if other grievance procedures are available and not exhausted
Procedural_Issue: Failure to exhaust internal harassment complaint process
Outcome_on_Merits: Not reached – dismissed on procedural grounds
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Commission's decision found procedurally fair and reasonable
Key_Evidence_Considered: Applicant was given 90 days by Chief of Defence Staff to file harassment complaint but did not
Legal_Framework: Federal human rights law, administrative law principles
Applicant_Challenge: Commission’s refusal to hear complaint based on unexhausted remedies
Court_Result: Dismissed – no recourse due to unexhausted procedures
Legal_Rule_Source: s. 41(1)(a) of the Canadian Human Rights Act
Evidence_Type: Procedural record, notice of available internal process
Resolution_Mechanism: Internal grievance process deemed appropriate first step
Legal_Provision: s. 41(1)(a) of the Canadian Human Rights Act
Authority: Canadian Human Rights Commission, Federal Court
Legal_Provision_Cited: s. 41(1)(a) of the Canadian Human Rights Act
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Failure to exhaust reasonably available internal procedures
Applicable_Process: Internal harassment complaint process within Department of National Defence
Outcome_of_Review: No error found in Commission's decision
Jurisdiction: Federal jurisdiction – Canadian Human Rights Act
Governing_Rule: s. 41(1)(a) of the Canadian Human Rights Act
